results.title: Reading planet
results.creator_credit: Pawel Kuczynski, H G Simons Productions and Study Sources Unlimited
results.brief_description: Prism a young alien from the planet Reading is given the task of improving the reading skills of five earth students. Through their various adventures the audience is introduced to techniques such as deriving meaning from context, visualisation, etc.

results.title: To play the King
results.creator_credit: Paul Seed, Ken Riddington and BBC
results.brief_description: Ian Richardson is chilling in his portrayal of the now Prime Minister, Francis Urquhart. Determined to keep his power intact, Urquhart is challenged by the new King; a man with liberal ideals which set him on a collision course with the Prime Minister. Although Urquhart upholds the principles of the monarchy, he does not respect the man and therefore plans to topple him from his throne. Aided by a beautiful and cunning political assistant and egged on by his scheming wife, Urquhart is determined to remain the man pulling the strings.

results.title: Time scrambler
results.creator_credit: Pawel Kuczynski, Henriette Simons, H Simons and Landmark Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Reading planet”.
The Time Scrambler has locked five students into a lost time frame. Designed to teach students to use a time line and to recognise sequencing cues in the reading selections. Tells how Prism, an 11 year old alien/teacher instructs his earth students in time sequence when the students become confused about the sequence of events in a story.

results.title: Welfare [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Frederick Wiseman, Welfare Films and Zipporah Films
results.brief_description: The Waverley Welfare Center in Manhattan has to cope with an expanding population and shrinking resources. More than any other Wiseman film, Welfare is about an institution under pressure as it is required to take on more and more functions. The bureaucratic response tends to be to classify (with an attendant vocabulary) rather than tackle the basic problem of just distribution in what amounts to a cycle of deprivation, in which ‘clients must repeatedly present themselves as devoid of all economic support and moral strength in order to qualify for financial help and that may never be adequate in such a situation’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frederick Wiseman, Welfare Films and Zipporah Films

results.title: Welcome to the Waks family [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Rod Freedman, Documentary Films, Film Australia and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: Filmed over a period of five years, this fascinating documentary provides a rare insight into a Melbourne orthodox Jewish family, but not just any family, as the Waks family is probably the largest in Australia with 17 individual children to the same two parents. Zephaniah and his wife Chaya had their first eight children in Israel until they migrated to Melbourne in 1984 settling in East St Kilda, an area renowned for its Jewish community, schools and Synagogues. They follow the Lubavitch branch of Judaism which has many restrictions and strict daily laws and rituals including prayer three to four times a day, no visits to the cinema or theatre, no reading of novels, no listening or playing of popular mainstream music, no television except for educational or religious purposes and no mixing of boys and girls except within the family. Both parents expect their children to follow and practise these beliefs including finding a marriage partner through the “Matchmaker”. However, through the daily rituals, school, the on-going social and religious celebrations, no child is neglected or lacking in attention. There appears to be respect, love and a unity amongst the family members even in the most challenging of circumstances as shown by Zephaniah and Chaya in their patience and caring, and tolerance (even when hurt and disappointed) when one of their teenage sons turns away from his religion and joins the Israeli Army. Family is everything and compassion and compromise sometimes necessary to maintain the family unity. The Waks are not rich financially but they are rich where it matters in other aspects of life, particularly family and religion. An intriguing biographical documentary featuring archival footage, stills, location shots in New York, interviews with various members of the family and commentary by the filmmaker who is also a long time friend of Zephaniah’s.

results.title: To live until you die
results.creator_credit: Eric Davidson, Andrew Maclear, Time-Life Films and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A documentary about Elisabeth Kubler-Ross and her work. Doctor Kubler-Ross is a trained medical practitioner and psychiatrist and has specialised in the care of dying patients - both young and old. Her work concentrates on the re-education of people’s attitudes towards dying, and a great deal of her time is spent, not only with patients, but also lecturing to others.

results.title: Welcome to the dollhouse
results.brief_description: Todd Solondz’s debut feature is a darkly funny and bleak tale of the trials and horrors of high school outsiders. “Welcome to the Dollhouse” exacts with excruciating and all too familiar detail the ritualistic and cut throat pecking order of a New Jersey high school. In the title role Solondz has found an unusual alter ego in eleven year old Dawn Wiener (Heather Matarazzo), whose thick glasses, social awkwardness and infantile dress sense have marked her with the cruel nickname of Wiener dog. This has made her into the prime target for every high school bully including Brandon (Brendon Sexton the 3rd), a vicious delinquent who is constantly threatening to rape Dawn after school. Brandon’s promise of sexual assault become one of the many obstacles Dawn must deal with in her unrelenting journey through puberty, along with unsympathetic parents, a younger prissy sister that is unbearably wholesome, and a painful crush on the dreamy school rebel Steve (Eric Mabius). Cast also includes Daria Kalinina, Matthew Faber and Dimitri Iervolino. (Awards: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at the 1996 Sundance Film Festival)

results.title: To live till you die
results.creator_credit: Robert Morgan, J.C. Sheers, ABC, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, National Educational Television and Rediffusion
results.brief_description: Explores the problems of old age and retirement in two different societies. 83-year-old Olivia is placed in an old people’s home in Sweden’s welfare state, in contrast to the great grandfather of the southern Italian Filazzola family, who still plays a part in supporting the family.

results.title: To know the Hurons
results.creator_credit: George Appleby, Haverand Productions and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates a new style of excavation used for archaeological work at the Draper site north of Toronto where there are remains of a large Huron village. With financial support from Transport Canada and the Archaeological Surveys of Canada, all the findings were fed into a computer, resulting in far more comprehensive information than would have been the case under the old system. Voice and narration: William D. Finlayson. (Award: Verona.)
